title.text: TRAPACC and TRAPACC Sat PARSEME Shared Task 2018: Neural Transition Tagging of Verbal Multiword Expressions

entities.text: Neural Transition Tagging of Verbal Multiword Expressions

abstractContent.text: We describe the TRAPACC system and its variant TRAPACC S that participated in the closed track of the PARSEME Shared Task 2018 on labeling verbal multiword expressions (VMWEs).
TRA-PACC is a modified arc-standard transition system based on Constant and Nivre's (2016) model of joint syntactic and lexical analysis in which the oracle is approximated using a classifier.
For TRAPACC, the classifier consists of a data-independent dimension reduction and a convolutional neural network (CNN) for learning and labelling transitions.
TRAPACC S extends TRAPACC by replacing the softmax layer of the CNN with a support vector machine (SVM).
We report the results obtained for 19 languages, for 8 of which our system yields the best results compared to other participating systems in the closed-track of the shared task.

introductionContent.text: The PARSEME shared task on VMWE identification) is an initiative aiming at improving automatic methods for VMWE identification in a highly multilingual context.

entities.text: PARSEME shared task on VMWE identification

introductionContent.text: To foster this initiative, the 2018 shared task provides test and training corpora, annotated with VMWEs in 19 different languages , and a framework to evaluate supervised methods for identifying VMWEs (.
In this paper, we present TRAPACC and its variant TRAPACC S that address the VMWE identification task using a neural transition system.

The general idea behind TRAPACC has been motivated by observations from the first edition of the shared task: showed that the modified arc-standard transition method by (hereinafter MAST) can be employed to outperform other systems in which VMWE identification is modeled as a sequence labeling task disregarding of their employed learning model, e.g., conditional random fields (CRFs) (, and bidirectional recurrent neural networks (.

Accordingly, we adapt MAST for the purpose of the PARSEME shared task; but, in contrast to, instead of using a linear SVM for learning and predicting transitions, we use a CNN preceded by a dimension reduction proposed in).
Furthermore, TRAPACC S extends the TRAPACC system by replacing the output softmax layer of the CNN with a kernel SVM.

The latter is motivated by research, such as and, that suggests using CNN combined with a more elaborate classifier (i.e., to use CNN only as a feature selection method) is likely to improve prediction performance.
The remainder of this paper is structured as follows: We describe our method in Section 2, we report results from the experiment and discuss them in Section 3.
